chapters.name: The Discipline of Computing
chapters.description: This chapter introduces the history of computing, from early calculating devices to modern computers. It covers the generations of computers and the fundamental concepts of hardware, software, and firmware.

questions.question: Who is known as the father of the computer?
What is the difference between hardware and software? Give an example of each.
questions.correctAnswer: Hardware refers to the physical components of a computer system, like the CPU, monitor, and keyboard. Software is a set of instructions or programs that tells the hardware what to do, such as an operating system (e.g., Windows) or an application (e.g., Microsoft Word).

chapters.name: Data Representation and Boolean Algebra
chapters.description: This chapter explores how data is represented inside a computer using various number systems (binary, octal, hexadecimal). It also introduces Boolean Algebra, logic gates, and theorems used in digital circuit design.

questions.question: The binary equivalent of the decimal number 10 is:
Which logic gate produces a high output (1) only when all its inputs are high?

chapters.name: Components of the Computer System
chapters.description: This chapter details the functional units of a computer system, including the Central Processing Unit (CPU) with its ALU and CU, memory hierarchy (RAM, ROM, Cache), input/output devices, and storage devices.

questions.question: Which component is known as the 'brain' of the computer?
What is the difference between RAM and ROM?
questions.correctAnswer: RAM (Random Access Memory) is volatile memory used for temporary storage of data that the CPU is actively using. ROM (Read-Only Memory) is non-volatile memory that stores firmware and boot-up instructions, and its contents cannot be easily changed.

chapters.name: Introduction to C++ Programming
chapters.description: This chapter introduces the C++ programming language, covering its basic structure, character set, tokens (keywords, identifiers, literals), and the fundamental concepts of variables and data types.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid keyword in C++?
What is the purpose of a semicolon (;) in a C++ statement?
questions.correctAnswer: In C++, the semicolon is a statement terminator. It indicates the end of one logical expression or instruction.

chapters.name: Data Types and Operators
chapters.description: This chapter details the fundamental data types in C++ (int, char, float, double, void), modifiers (signed, unsigned), and various operators including arithmetic, relational, logical, and assignment.

questions.question: What operator is used for finding the remainder of a division?
What is type casting in C++?
questions.correctAnswer: Type casting is a way to convert a variable from one data type to another. For example, converting a `float` to an `int` to truncate the decimal part.

chapters.name: Control Statements
chapters.description: This chapter explains how to control the flow of execution in a C++ program using decision-making statements (if, if-else, switch) and looping/iterative statements (for, while, do-while).

questions.question: Which loop is guaranteed to execute at least once?
What is the purpose of the 'break' statement in a switch case?
questions.correctAnswer: The 'break' statement is used to terminate the switch block. Without it, execution would 'fall through' to the next case, which is usually not the intended behavior.
